Before Egypt's revolution, one of every seven Egyptians made a living in the tourism industry.

NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson reports.
Hassan Abdel Ain chisels Islamic artwork onto a copper plate here at Khan el-Khalili.
It's a craft he's perfected over half a century in this market popular with foreign visitors, and it used to net him 20 sales a day.
(Foreign language spoken)
These days, the weathered-looking artisan says he's lucky he can sell even one plate.
Nearby, shopkeepers play dominoes in the narrow alleys while waiting for tourists who rarely come here anymore.
One store manager is Hisham Ahmed.
(Foreign language spoken)
He says a year ago this market was packed with foreigners during the cooler evening hours.
On this night, only a few Egyptians walk past without glancing at his wares.
(Foreign language spoken)
Ahmed says he and others in the tourist trade are suffering because of a revolution that everyone here hoped would improve Egyptian life.
Egypt's top tourism officials agree.
They say media reports of demonstrations that ousted Mubarak coupled with foreign travel warnings about the unrest have frightened away millions of tourists.
Senior Assistant Tourism Minister Hisham Zaazou says tourism in Egypt dropped by 35 percent overall in the first half of the year, compared to the same period in 2010.
That's meant a $3 billion loss to the Egyptian economy.
Zaazou says while Egypt's military rulers have more or less restored calm, the number of travelers has been slow to rebound.
I am worried and I think everybody working in this industry is worried, be this person an official or a private sector businessman, he is worried.
Yes, of course.
It's the matter of how can we restore and regain the consumer confidence again.
An executive with a major Egyptian tour company agrees.
Karim Aly, who is a vice president at the Cairo-based Emeco Travel, says he's never seen a rebound this slow, not even following terrorist attacks against tourists in Egypt.
I don't say we don't have business but having only 20 to 25 percent of the business promised for this year, this is a failure, a huge failure, because we are a company of 500 employees.
So how can I support 500 employees with 20 percent of the revenue?
He says dozens of his employees are on extended, unpaid leaves.
Cairo-based tour guides like Maha Mahmoud el Halwagy are also having a rough time of it.

There are few criminal justice issues more controversial or emotional than what to do with convicted child molesters after they have served their time.
Well known cases of abduction, rape and murder led all 50 states and the federal government to pass laws designed to protect children.
On release from prison, sex offenders must register their name, address and photograph, and that information is posted in online registries.
Many states and local governments also passed laws that bar sex offenders from living near places where children gather, like schools and playgrounds.
A new report from Human Rights Watch concludes that these laws may seem intuitively correct, but that they're based on faulty ideas and do little, if anything, to protect children.
They're also written so broadly, the report says, that they include many people who pose no threat to kids at all, and expose them to ridicule, hatred and sometimes violence.

Why sex offenders?
Well, a few years ago, we were doing a report on public housing and access to public housing for all former offenders.
And in the process of that research, we started collecting stories of former sex offenders who are having a particularly hard time reentering the community.
And so, we started to investigate.

And what we found along the way was, you know, not just that, the laws that you mentioned, the registration community notification, residence restriction laws have a pretty severe impact on former sex offenders.
The laws - there's very little evidence that they are actually preventing sexual violence and there is some evidence that they may be doing more harm than good.
And we felt like that was a very important report for us to release.
Mm-hmm.
More harm than good, how?
Well, these laws, as you mentioned before, are based on some myths that we have about convicted sex offenders.
Myths that I had myself before I started doing the research, that previously convicted sex offenders pose sort of the greatest danger towards our children in terms of sexual violence.
And that, you know, previously committed sex offenders have a really high recidivism rate.
What I found while I was researching this report is that 87 percent of sex crimes every year are committed by individuals who have no previous sex crimes convictions.
And three out of four sex offenders, convicted sex offenders, did not re-offend within sort of 15-year period upon release from prison.

So, while there may be previously convicted sex offenders who pose some risk to the community - and we want them to be monitored, and maybe we want them to be subject to some form of these laws - there are, by focusing all of our attention only on previously convicted sex offenders, we're really ignoring sort of the larger picture of sexual violence in this country, which is that, again, most sex crimes every year are not committed by someone who has a sex crime conviction.
And another important point or part of this is that most sex crimes, over 90 percent of sexual abuse against children is committed by someone that child knows or trusts, or love.
And so, stranger danger isn't - it's part of the problem, but it's not as big a part of the problem as I think is widely believed.

And so, again, when we focus all of our attention on previously convicted sex offenders, we're not able to really focus the public resources and have the public debate we need to be having about the real picture of sexual violence in this country, and what we can do to prevent it, and what we can do to make sure that there are no more victims.
